data.title: Accessibilty: allow highlight current line styling
data.body: Related to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5678, but I have always had trouble seeing which line my cursor is on, so I like to have a nice light transparent grey across the entire line (See screenshot) I'd like to be able to select my own line highlight style for my own accessibility concerns. Unfortunately the cursor is not in the screenshot, but it's a bright white vertical line for me.

data.title: Fixes 7369: report RunToCursorAction as not supported when session not stopped
data.body:
Fixes #7369: report `RunToCursorAction` as not supported when session not stopped

Other `DebugAction`s report as not enabled when VSCode is not in the correct state
for the action to run. However, `RunToCursorAction` inherits from `EditorAction`
which relies on an `IEnablementState` to report whether it's enabled, and it's
very specific to `EditorAction`s.

@isidorn

data.title: Pinned Diff Editor Does Not Retain Scroll Position After You Switch Back to it
data.body:
- VSCode Version: commit a3c38e902fc6dbe06d80f43d5cf527b066499f51
- OS Version: Mac OS X

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a diff editor
2. Pin the editor to stay by double clicking it in Open Editors
3. Scroll somewhere you will remember in this editor
4. Now open some other file from the explorer
5. Switch back to the diff editor and note that it does not retain the scroll position as other editors normally do when switching back.

![jun-07-2016 16-20-23](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11839736/15878229/2f3df006-2cce-11e6-9c4b-c0f09b8065cb.gif)

data.title: Fixes #7366 Remove leaked breakpoint after stopping with run-to-cursor
data.body:
Add a listener for the `exit` event as well to remove the generated breakpoint in `RunToCursorAction`.

@isidorn @weinand

data.title: Run to cursor to a previously executed line results in a leaked breakpoint
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: OS X

I understand this is a result of the implementation of RunToCursorAction, which basically creates a breakpoint at the specified location, continues the execution, and remove the breakpoint once it has been hit.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set a breakpoint and start debugging.
2. Select Run to cursor in the context menu for a line that won't be executed
3. Stop the program

Result: there is a leaked breakpoint where run to cursor was called.

![runtocursorbug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/637952/15877533/45f1b3f0-2cc9-11e6-85bb-3a82a03b1030.gif)

@isidorn @weinand

data.title: Support back/forward across preview editors
data.body:
This may be by design but it means you can't backtrack through preview files which is disorienting/not intuitive imo

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a file as a preview, click around
2. Open another file as a new preview
3. Trigger go back, notice the previous file won't popup

data.title: VSCode doesn't use correct or newest version of Git
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-insider (24e811aa)
- OS Version: Windows 7 SP 1 x64

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Install Git for Windows 1.8.3
2. Install Cygwin with Git 2.8.0
3. Start VSCode
4. Receive warning "You seem to have git 1.8.3 installed. Code works best with git >= 2.0.0."

**Expected Result:**

I'd expect VSCode to use the first item (earlier in my PATH) or the newest version.

**Actual Result:**

VSCode is using the last exe in my path from what i can tell.

**Environment Info:**

```
C:\Users\brandon>where git
D:\cygwin64\bin\git.exe
C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\cmd\git.exe

C:\Users\brandon>git --version
git version 2.8.0

C:\Users\brandon>D:\cygwin64\bin\git.exe --version
git version 2.8.0

C:\Users\brandon>"C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\cmd\git.exe" --version
git version 1.8.3.msysgit.0

C:\Users\brandon>echo %PATH%
D:\cygwin64\bin;C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files\Microsoft Shared\Windows Live;D:\PHP;D:\Python\;C:\Windows\system32;C:\Windows;C:\Windows\System32\Wbem;C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\;C:\Program Files (x86)\Universal Extractor;C:\Program Files (x86)\Universal Extractor\bin;C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\110\Tools\Binn\;C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\cmd;C:\Program Files (x86)\MySQL\MySQL Utilities 1.3.4\;D:\Cygwin\bin;C:\Windows\SysWOW64;C:\Program Files\Perforce;C:\Program Files\Common Files\Autodesk Shared\;C:\Program Files (x86)\Autodesk\Backburner\;C:\Program Files (x86)\NVIDIA Corporation\PhysX\Common;%USERPROFILE%\.dnx\bin;C:\Program Files\Microsoft DNX\Dnvm\;C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\8.1\Windows Performance Toolkit\;C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\TypeScript\1.0\;C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\120\Tools\Binn\;C:\Go\bin;C:\Program Files\nodejs\;C:\Program Files (x86)\Skype\Phone\;C:\HashiCorp\Vagrant\bin;C:\Qt\Qt5.1.1\5.11\mingw48_32\bin;D:\cygwin64\bin;C:\Program Files\Common Files\Microsoft Shared\Windows Live;C:\Users\brandon\AppData\Local\atom\bin;C:\Rust\bin;C:\Users\brandon\AppData\Roaming\npm;C:\Python27;C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code Insiders\bin
```

data.title: Follow auto save setting configuration when creating new files from actions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
We have some actions that result in new files being created in the workspace. We should respect the auto save setting and only save the file to disk if auto save is enabled. Otherwise we can open the file dirty until saved.

**Old summary**
- Have `"files.autoSave": "afterDelay"` in your settings
- Open code on a new folder
- Create a `hello.js` file and open it
- Wait for the (ugly) green lightbulb in the bottom right corner to appear; click it and choose to create a `jsconfig.json` file.

The newly created `jsconfig.json` file will not be automatically saved. It will instead display the unsaved icon and wait for me to save it.

data.title: Breakpoint is duplicated if line is moved while editing the breakpoint condition

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0 stable
- OS Version: Tried it on OS X 10.10.5 and Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a file where breakpoints are supported
2. Set a breakpoint at any line
3. Right click the breakpoint and select "Edit Breakpoint"
4. While the "Edit Breakpoint" dialog is open, move the line where the breakpoint is set
5. Hit Enter to confirm the "Edit Breakpoint" dialog
6. The breakpoint gets duplicated, but it should just move like it does if escape is pressed instead of Enter.

Note that this reproes without actually starting debugging.

Here's a recording of the repro:

![double_breakpoint_repro](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/637952/15873703/b6abbed4-2cb4-11e6-8a33-913c7251c05c.gif)

@isidorn @weinand

data.title: Give option to set the font of the hidden console window used by winpty

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

THE PROBLEM: At least under cp936 and using TrueType fonts, when rendering some characters, like `λ`, Windows will measure the real character width of the console font chosen, and allocate console cells to display them. (The full alglrithm of how character widths are calculated is listed in [consolelib.cs#L676](https://github.com/lzybkr/PSReadLine/blob/0ffd1b2351214f1f25a433060a6c75a29c59c90f/PSReadLine/ConsoleLib.cs#L676).) (ps. I am curious about why this algorithm is not ported to non-DBCS code pages, like 65001, given that the Console can actually render these characters, the result is not layouted well.)

Therefore if the font used for the hidden console is inconsistent with the font configured in VSCode, the character widths may be incorrect. For the `λ`, most Windows users under cp936/932 will see this character rendered and layouted in full-width in the real console (because this lambda in NSimSun and MS Gothic is full-width), but Code will treat them as half-width, causing incorrect layout.

THE SOLUTION: Give option to set the font of the hidden console used by winpty in sync with the font used in Code.

A sample font package: [Inziu](http://be5invis.github.io/Iosevka/inziu.html). (Inziu Iosevka SC for 936, Inziu Iosevka J for 932.)

data.title: Running build task in Code approximately 50% slower than in terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run build task in Code (i.e. gulp dist)
2. Run same command in cmd.exe (or integrated terminal)

Expected result:
- Tasks should take about the same amount of time

Actual result:
- Build task takes ~20 seconds to finish in Code, while it takes ~13 seconds in terminal.

data.title: [html] Closing markup tags should auto-format/indent

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows (10.0.10586.0)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new HTML file
2. Type the following into the editor

``` html
<html>
  <head>
```
1. Go to a newline (hit enter, should be on line 3 of the editor)
2. Type in `</head>`
3. Notice that the closing head tag stays indented as if it was a child element

**Desired result**

When closing tags, VS Code should auto-indent (in this case move `</head>` to the same indentation as the `<head>` tag on the previous line).

data.title: Fix removal of /usr/bin link when upgrading package
data.body: This should be fix for #5840 (but I've not tested it)

data.title: TypeScript Intellisense very slow with some projects
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

I'm using [angular2-webpack-starter](https://github.com/AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter), and after cloning the repo and doing an `npm install` typescript intellisense is extremely slow.
One thing I've noticed is that the `exclude` list paths in **tsconfig.json** are written like this:

``` json
{
  "exclude": [
    "./node_modules",
    "./typings/main.d.ts",
    "./typings/main"
  ]
}
```

But once I remove the dot slashes and restart VS Code things seem to be fixed and intellisense works fast:

``` json
{
  "exclude": [
    "node_modules",
    "typings/main.d.ts",
    "typings/main"
  ]
}
```

I've reported the issue AngularClass/angular2-webpack-starter#660 but it seems the problem lies with VS Code since I've tried Atom with its typescript plugin and it works properly with that starter by default.

data.title: UI bugs - missing all the debug buttons and indicators
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. launch visual code with the cordova plugin enabled
2. try to add break points in the editor

When doing this - all the visual indications of a break point are gone. On my mac I can visually see a red dot indicating a breakpoint. Also in the debug window, the "play" button is missing and when launched (cordova) , I can't see the "play", "stop" etc. buttons that I can on my mac. This is tested on two windows machine (both window 7 version).

data.title: copying (Ctrl + C) selected text from the terminal terminates the current application that is running in it
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2
- OS Version: Windows 7, x65

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the terminal from within VS code
2. Do `git log`
3. Observe a first page of the command output (while the pager is awaiting for continuation)
4. Select a piece of the output text.
5. Attempt to copy the selected piece using `Ctrl + C`
6. Observe `git log` terminated.

Expected: text copied while application is still running

:+1:

data.title: Line breaks in Windows integrated terminal ignored when pasted

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Windows 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Copy several lines of code (open notepad, type mkdir directory1[enter]mkdir directory2)
2. Paste code in integrated terminal, it pastes as a single command 'mkdir directory1mkdirdirectory2' with any line breaks removed.

This happens on both default cmd.exe integrated terminal and powershell integrated terminal.

data.title: Backspace, left and right in Windows integrated terminal cause prompt to go out of sync in Git bash

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body:

- OS Version: Windows 10
- Terminal: Git bash

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Invoke the new integrated terminal
2. type command
3. backspace to delete some characters
4. Notice that while the command executed will be accurate to what was typed, the display of the line will be out of sync with the internal state of the terminal.

data.title: terminal.integrated.shell.windows setting Doesn't support environment variables

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Win 10 enterprise preview

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Set user setting to  "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "%programfiles%\Git\git-bash.exe"
2.  Open terminal ctrl+`

Expected:
Terminal opens.

Actual:
Terminal window flickers and closes (presumably crashes).

Workaround:
Use explicit pathing like "C:\Program Files\Git\git-bash.exe" instead.
